Award.AwardTitle: A Regional Partnership to Improve Access to and Academic Quality of Technician Education for the Incumbent Worker

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses two persistent issues in higher education: maintaining academic rigor in online technical coursework and improving cooperation between colleges' academic and workforce development units to make continued technical education accessible to incumbent (currently employed) workers. Research shows that concerns about loss of rigor are a significant factor in preventing the adoption of accessible delivery models such as online learning. Demonstrating effective methods of preserving rigor while making technical education more accessible will spur their adoption and make for-credit technical education a viable option for the incumbent workforce. Further, the project eliminates the competition between colleges' academic and workforce development units by offering workforce development a superior, for-credit product to sell to employers in lieu of non-credit offerings.

Madisonville Community College (MCC) will provide technical assistance to partner colleges in three states to adapt and disseminate its Advanced Integrated Technology (AIT) curriculum and delivery model. Each partner college is part of a statewide system of community and technical colleges that provides a natural outlet for project dissemination. The project extends work developed with prior NSF support, during which a hybrid online competency based, college credit curriculum was developed to make technical education more accessible to employers and incumbent workers for skills upgrades. Courses are broken into competency-based, college-credit modules that allow students to target specific skills in four core areas - Mechanical, Electrical, Fluid Power, and Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs). Modules will be customized to target specific employer and employee training needs, and skills demonstrations are being delivered in a flexibly scheduled laboratory setting enabling students to schedule application exercises without sacrificing work time. The work of this project focuses on adapting the MCC curriculum and delivery model to conform to a variety of organizational cultures, policy and procedure frameworks, and employer and employee needs. Educating the incumbent workforce also presents special student support and advising challenges. MCC will make effective use of a career coach position who assists incumbent workers with the admission and registration process and monitors each worker's course performance and credential progress. MCC is working with partner colleges to identify their incumbent work advising and academic support needs and assisting them in adapting the position accordingly. In addition, partner colleges are conducting post-enrollment research to identify incumbent workers' challenges and unmet needs in order to create a documented tool kit of strategies and local support services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Madisonville Community College (Madisonville, KY) partnered with three other community colleges - West Kentucky Community and Technical College (Paducah, KY); Ivy Tech Community College (Bloomington, IN); and Chattanooga State Community College (Chattanooga, TN) - to evaluate the effectiveness of the hybrid online delivery model developed by MCC in a previous NSF-ATE project ("Advanced Industrial Integrated Technology (AIIT) Initiative" DUE #0903261) when applied to the advanced manufacturing associate degree programs in the partners' diverse service areas. After year 1, West Kentucky CTC embraced a different delivery model for its advanced manufacturing program, and their subaward was terminated. They were replaced in the project by Webster County Area Technology Center (ATC), a secondary school in MCC's service area, who carried out a modified work plan designed to serve high school students in advanced manufacturing.

The project's most successful element was the replication of a career coach position to interact with the incumbent worker seeking upskill training - the primary target audience for the programming offered. This liaison was paramount in ensuring the success of incumbent workers in the program, and qualitative research conducted during the project period showed that these students valued the support provided by the career coach. Consequently, both Ivy Tech and Chattanooga State sustained their career coach positions post-grant.

Another valuable finding from the qualitative research was that incumbent workers had an aversion to online delivery of content, not necessarily because of a deficit in their computer skills, but because of preconceived notions about the value of online content informed by their experiences with poor quality online training provided by their employers. The inclusion of a hands-on lab component in the program mitigated those concerns substantially. It is clear that the hybrid online delivery model must be marketed carefully and holistically to differentiate it from the potentially ineffective online training incumbent workers have experienced in the past. 

The project also revealed that the approach to delivering flexibly scheduled in-person lab work must be a function of an institution's available resources and instructional culture. MCC's model did not directly translate to either Ivy Tech or Chattanooga State, but both partners implemented a modified model that was successful. Rather than providing pre-scheduled extended lab hours, Ivy Tech adopted an appointment-based lab model. Chattanooga State devised a check-out system for lab equipment that is portable enough for students to transport easily, and a system of equipment sharing for less mobile apparatus. Ultimately, both models had similar effects in their respective service areas, making upskill training more accessible to incumbent workers with schedules that do not lend themselves to traditional instructional models.

Despite coming to the project late and dealing with the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic during the project's extension year, Webster County ATC succesfully adapted and implemented a dual credit manufacturing pathway, including the NSF-funded STEM Guitar project. Project results for Webster County ATC were comparable to those attained by the Hopkins County ATC as part of MCC's NSF-ATE project entitled "Creating a High School Pipeline for the Next Generation of Manufacturing Employees" (DUE #1601359).
